doc.title: Base Metals Tracker: Copper Surplus To Keep LME Price Stable Into Year-End, While Anti-Involution Price Support For Aluminium Unwinds
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Base Metals Tracker Copper Surplus To Keep LME Price Stable Into Year-End While Anti-Involution Price Support For Alumin_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: LME base metals prices have been relatively stable over the past month as expectations of Fed rate cuts and cost support to some commodities (aluminium) from anti- involution headlines have been met with a simultaneous loosening in physical markets and weaker China activity data. We hold to our year- end LME copper price forecast of \(\) 9,700/t\(\) \ \(100/t\) below current levels), and remain bearish LME aluminium as H1 2025 cost deflation continued to flow through.

Policies: We believe that the support to aluminium prices from anti- involution headlines in China will be short- lived, with policies likely to provide a floor to alumina prices, but not actively boost them. SHFE alumina futures rallied by almost \(30\%\) between May and July. This was driven by the market pricing the risk of cuts to domestic alumina refining capacity as China seeks to tackle overcapacity issues and excessive price competition across many industrial sectors. This translates into a \(- \mathbb{S}200 / \mathrm{t}\) increase in the cost of production for domestic Chinese aluminium smelters, roughly equal to the \(7\%\) increase in the SHFE aluminium price since the Q2 low, bringing the LME price higher with it. We have previously noted that the Chinese alumina market was heading towards significant overcapacity due to investment in new refining capacity despite potential demand growth being limited by the primary aluminium production cap. 3Mt of alumina refining capacity was added in July alone, increasing domestic capacity by \(>3\%\) . While we expect anti- involution policies to slow these investments, therefore limiting the downside to the alumina price lows reached earlier this year, we have not seen signs of cuts to existing capacity, which would be needed to actively tighten the market. Instead, Chinese alumina inventory is at the highest level since early 2022 and still rising. Meanwhile, the impact on the Australian OB alumina spot price has been limited, suggesting continued loose seaborne market. As a result, we expect ore rally in onshore alumina prices to continue to unwind over the remainder of Q3, while the impact of the H1 fall in global bauxite and alumina prices will come to be fully reflected in smelters' costs in H2 2025. We note that although Guinean bauxite exports have moved lower in H2 - due to both seasonality and the cancellation of mining licenses - global bauxite exports are still up by \(18\%\) YoY YTD, with no imminent concerns of a shortage.

Beyond alumina, we see limited impact of anti- involution on our global metals balances. In the steel sector, we are yet to see signs of lower production in high frequency data and believe that the weak labor market makes it difficult to implement large- scale and aggressive production cuts.
Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC

Price Table 4  Price Forecasts 5  Copper: Physical Market Indicators 6  Copper: Supply & Demand Tracker 7  Copper: Forecast Tracker 8  Aluminium: Physical Market Indicators 9  Aluminium: Supply & Demand Tracker 10  Zinc: Physical Market Indicators 11  Nickel: Physical Market Indicators 12  Speculative Positioning 13  Disclosure Appendix 14

Meanwhile, although the targeting of the solar sector poses some downside risk to our base metals demand forecasts, we see this as limited as we already made a significant revision to our solar demand forecasts in June following Chinese policy changes. For now, broad activity data in China appears to be weakening, and apparent consumption growth of copper and aluminium has slowed in recent months, in line with our expectations.

COMEX Copper Remains Attractive Due To Refined Copper Tariff Risk: Despite a \(25\%\) collapse in the COMEX copper price in July following President Trump's announcement that refined copper would be exempt from the Section 232 copper tariff and US stocks remaining at 180 days of consumption (vs. 8- 9 days in the rest of the world), the COMEX copper price continues to trade at a \(\sim 1\%\) premium to the LME price at the front of the curve, rising to \(>5\%\) in 2027 futures. We believe that the premium in near- dated futures is being driven by continued market pricing of a potential tariff on refined copper. This could come well- before the 2027 date suggested in the Section 232 announcement1, as the tariff in its current form is likely to have limited impact on US copper import reliance. Beyond near- dated contracts, we think that the widening of the COMEX- LME differential along the futures curve is being driven by the wider COMEX spreads, driven by high US inventory.

While LME stocks remain relatively low, we reiterate that we see no near- term risk of a global copper shortage. Including unreported US stocks, global copper stocks are up more than 500kt YTD, but this overstates the surplus; we estimate the YTD stock build is 290kt based on our bottom- up supply and demand model (with determines our global balance). This discrepancy suggests a draw in non- US unreported stocks. Regardless, even if 290kt stock build is substantial, and we highlight upside risk to our 100kt 2025 surplus. Given copper is currently trading above our Dec- 25 forecast of \(\) 9,700\(/t, we close our Long Copper Jun- 26 Call Spreads (closing level:\) \ \(196\) trade recommendation (opened on 25 Feb. 2025 at \(\) 187\(/t).

European Defense Spending To Provide Another Boost to Base Metals Demand: We recently highlighted the potential boost to global base metals demand from higher European defense spending. While the defense sector only accounts for \(2 - 3\%\) of global industrial metals demand currently, we estimated that an increase in Euro area military spending from \(1.9\%\) in 2024 to \(2.7\%\) of GDP by 2027 could translate into a cumulative \(6\%\) boost to European industrial metals demand by 2027, and global demand increases of \(0.4\%\) for steel, \(0.9\%\) for copper, and \(1.3\%\) for nickel. Furthermore, defense spending also includes infrastructure investment, including cybersecurity, adding upside risk to our \(3\%\) growth forecast for grid and power infrastructure demand.

Source: S&P Global Market Intelligence, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
